description: From Middle English expedient, from Old French expedient, from Latin expediens (stem expedient-), present participle of expedire (“to bring forward, to dispatch, to expedite; impers. to be profitable, serviceable, advantageous, expedient”), from ex (“out”) + pēs (“foot, hoof”).

adjectives.description: expedient (comparative more expedient, superlative most expedient)

entries.meaning: Suitable to effect some desired end or the purpose intended.
examples: Most people, faced with a decision, will choose the most expedient option.

entries.meaning: Affording short-term benefit, often at the expense of the long-term.
Governed by self-interest, often short-term self-interest.
A method or means for achieving a particular result, especially when direct or efficient; a resource.
examples: He would never let her know that he was aware of the strange expedient to which she had been driven by her great distress.
